etymologies: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘outward’): from late Latin extrinsecus ‘outward’, from Latin extrinsecus ‘outwardly’, based on exter ‘outer’; the ending was altered under the influence of -ic

definitions: not part of the essential nature of someone or something; coming or operating from outside

examples.text: a complex interplay of extrinsic and intrinsic factors
reasons extrinsic to the music itself

shortDefinitions: not part of essential nature of person or thing

definitions: (of a muscle, such as an eye muscle) having its origin some distance from the part which it moves.
shortDefinitions: (of muscle, such as eye muscle) having its origin some distance from part which it moves
